snippet: Police chiefs in 15 cities were dismissed or reassigned, a move analysts saw as part of an effort to disrupt a corruption investigation.
abstract: Turkish government reshuffles the police force yet again and seeks to expand its power over the judiciary in a move that one former justice minister likens to a coup; analysts say both actions appear calculated to fend off a widening corruption investigation that has plunged the government of Prime Min Recep Tayyip Erdogan into its worst crisis since it came to power more than a decade ago.

byline.original: By DAN BILEFSKY and SEBNEM ARSU
byline.contributor: Dan Bilefsky reported from Paris, and Sebnem Arsu from Istanbul.

lead_paragraph: Police chiefs in 15 cities were dismissed or reassigned, a move analysts saw as part of an effort to disrupt a corruption investigation.

headline.main: Turkish Government, Shaking Up Police, Now Seeks More Power Over Judiciary
headline.print_headline: Turkish Government, Shaking Up Police, Now Seeks More Power Over Judiciary
